title: Iron, Sugar, and Mirrors Rewired Humanity
tldr: The great man theory of history is an illusion. Human civilization was not shaped by kings and generals but by materials: iron democratized warfare and agriculture, salt and sugar built empires through biological necessity and industrial exploitation, and mirrors fundamentally altered human psychology by creating the modern concept of individual identity.

article:
## The Hidden Authors of History

Open any high school history textbook and you will find it organized by the same familiar scaffolding: dates, kings, battles, treaties. The year 1066, William the Conqueror, the Battle of Hastings. The year 1492, Columbus, the voyage across the Atlantic. Napoleon. Caesar. The great man theory of history, endlessly rehearsed. It is a compelling narrative device, but it obscures a far more profound truth about human civilization.

The true authors of history are not people at all. They are materials. Substances. Stuff.

This is not merely a metaphor. The evidence suggests that materials do not simply serve human purposes like passive tools selected from a toolbox. They actively reshape economies, dictate social hierarchies, and as we shall see with one remarkable material, may have fundamentally altered the structure of human psychological experience. We tend to think of ourselves as masters of the physical world, choosing which resources to exploit and when. The historical record suggests the opposite: that the properties of materials have determined the trajectory of civilizations with an inevitability that no emperor ever possessed.

## The Danish Bureaucrat Who Reorganized Prehistory

To understand how materials shaped history, we must first understand how we learned to see history through materials at all. The story begins not with an adventurer excavating lost cities, but with a bureaucrat organizing a museum.

In the early 1800s, a Danish antiquarian named Christian Jorgensen Thomsen was given what must have seemed an impossibly tedious assignment. The National Museum in Copenhagen had accumulated a massive, chaotic collection of antiquities. Swords were piled alongside pottery, ornaments jumbled with agricultural tools, everything dating back thousands of years with no coherent system of classification. Thomsen's job was the ultimate spring cleaning project for human history.

Thomsen was not a field archaeologist. He never led expeditions to exotic locations or unearthed buried temples. He was, in the most modern sense, a data analyst. And as he sorted through the chaos of Copenhagen's collection, he noticed something that would restructure our entire understanding of the human past.

The pattern he observed was not about artistic style or the beauty of objects. It was about context. Stone tools were never found in the same burial layers as iron tools. Never. Bronze artifacts appeared with iron only in later archaeological layers. There was a sequence, a progression that could not be coincidental.

Thomsen realized that humanity had not always had access to all materials simultaneously. There were distinct technological epochs: an era when only stone was available, then a period when bronze dominated, and finally an age characterized by iron. This simple observation produced what we now call the Three Age System, the standard scaffolding for understanding prehistory that every museum and university still employs.

But knowing the order of these ages is merely the beginning. The far more important question is why these transitions occurred, and what they did to human society when they did.

## The Aristocracy of Bronze

The transition from bronze to iron is typically explained in the simplest possible terms: iron is harder than bronze, so obviously humanity upgraded. This explanation is not merely incomplete; it fundamentally misunderstands the dynamics at play.

To make bronze, you need an alloy of two ingredients: copper and tin. Copper is relatively abundant. Deposits exist throughout the Mediterranean and Middle East. But tin is geologically rare, one of the scarcest metals that ancient civilizations required. If you were a civilization in Mesopotamia and wanted tin, you could not simply dig for it locally. You had to trade, and you had to trade over staggering distances.

Archaeological evidence reveals tin trade routes stretching from mines in modern-day Afghanistan all the way to Cornwall in southwestern England, thousands of miles of organized commerce to obtain a single ingredient. This requirement created an entire economic infrastructure: merchant classes to manage logistics, ships to cross seas, and most importantly, a wealthy elite to fund and protect these trade networks.

Bronze was, by structural necessity, an aristocratic material. The metal of the one percent. It appeared in prestige items, jewelry, and weapons for the powerful. A king or high-ranking general might possess a bronze sword and bronze armor. But the average farmer? Probably still using stone tools generations after bronze was discovered. The cost and scarcity of bronze simply did not permit its democratization.

This was a top-down technology that reinforced existing hierarchies rather than disrupting them. Bronze did not transform the lives of ordinary people because ordinary people could never afford it.

## The Chemical Revolution That Toppled Kings

Iron changed everything, but not for the reason most people assume.

Iron is one of the most abundant elements on Earth. It exists in rocks, in bogs, virtually everywhere. Unlike tin, iron requires no international supply chain. A village could potentially find iron ore within ten miles of its borders. But there was a catch, and it was a significant one: temperature.

Copper melts at approximately 1,000 degrees Celsius, a temperature achievable in a good pottery kiln that ancient civilizations had mastered. Iron, however, requires temperatures exceeding 1,500 degrees Celsius to truly liquefy. For centuries, ancient technology simply could not reliably achieve these temperatures.

This created a strange historical paradox. People knew about iron. They could see it, could obtain small quantities of it. But they treated it almost like a precious stone because they could not effectively work it. Some of the earliest iron artifacts were not even smelted from terrestrial ore; they were fashioned from meteorites. Star metal. Iron that fell from the heavens and was considered divine, rarer and more precious than gold.

A longstanding theory called the tin shortage hypothesis proposed that humanity switched to iron because the bronze trade routes collapsed. According to this view, civilizations ran out of tin and were forced to use the inferior iron that was readily available. Necessity as the mother of invention. Iron as the backup plan.

But chemical analyses of bronze objects from Syria and Cyprus during the supposed transition period tell a different story. Bronze objects from the 12th and 11th centuries BCE still contained plenty of tin. There was no sudden drop in quality, no desperate substitution of inferior materials. The tin supply remained functional.

The switch to iron was not about scarcity. It was about innovation, specifically a process called carburization.

Pure smelted iron is actually quite soft. A sword made of pure iron will bend the first time it strikes a shield. Not a useful military technology. But if you heat iron in a furnace in prolonged contact with charcoal, which is carbon, the iron absorbs carbon atoms. Through quenching, rapidly cooling the metal in water, the crystal structure freezes in place. The result is a case-hardened material that is significantly harder than bronze and holds an edge far better.

Cyprus appears to be where this technology truly accelerated. Archaeological evidence includes innovative weapons like the iron pike from Tomb 417 at Lapithos, a weapon of war rather than a ceremonial object. Once the carburization code was cracked, humanity possessed a metal superior to bronze with raw materials available virtually everywhere.

This was the democratization of metal. The humblest plowman could now have an iron plowshare attached to his wooden plow. Iron tips allowed farmers to till soil deeper, break up heavy clay that wood and stone could never penetrate, clear forests faster. More food meant population explosions. And on the darker side, armies could suddenly be equipped on a massive scale. Bronze Age armies were small and elite because equipment was prohibitively expensive. Iron Age armies could arm thousands of conscripts with cheap spears.

Iron did not simply improve upon bronze. It toppled the entire elite structure of the Bronze Age and reshaped social hierarchies from the bottom up. The melting point of an element determined the political structure of civilizations.

## The Only Rock We Eat

The agricultural revolution that iron enabled created a new problem: a biological crisis that only geology could solve.

Salt is the only rock that humans eat. This fact creates a massive biological divide between the hunter and the farmer. Hunter-gatherers who lived on diets of red meat obtained sufficient sodium chloride naturally from animal flesh. Their biological imperative for salt was satisfied by their existing diet.

But the moment the Neolithic Revolution took hold and humanity began eating cereals, grains, and vegetables, sodium intake crashed. Farming populations found themselves biologically starving for a mineral that their bodies absolutely required to function. Biology drove geology. Humans had to find the rock because their bodies demanded it.

Salt became the first truly international commodity, but its value extended far beyond dietary necessity. The preservation power of salt built complex civilizations. Before refrigeration, a caught fish had to be consumed almost immediately or it would rot. Decay is the enemy of history. But a fish packed in salt could be transported five hundred miles inland. Armies on the march could be fed weeks away from any food source. Surplus could be stored for winter.

Salt allowed civilization to extend its reach beyond the immediate harvest. It enabled cities to exist far from food production, armies to campaign for extended periods, and trade networks to span continents. And because salt was so essential, so critical to basic survival, it became a goldmine for governments.

The first state monopoly was likely salt. Governments recognized immediately that everyone required this substance to live, making it the perfect target for taxation. The English word 'salary' derives from the Latin salarium, the allowance given to Roman soldiers specifically to purchase salt. The phrase 'worth his salt' literally meant worth the cost of keeping him alive.

But the power to tax a biological necessity proved volatile. History records major flashpoints that were essentially salt riots. The French Revolution was partially fueled by universal hatred of the gabelle, the despised French salt tax. In 1930, Mahatma Gandhi led his famous Salt March to the sea, where he simply picked up a handful of salty mud in defiance of the British Empire's monopoly on salt production in India. The protest highlighted that colonial powers were attempting to control a basic element of life itself.

Something now regarded as a cheap condiment was once a geopolitical lever capable of toppling empires.

## White Crystal, Black History

If salt created empires through biological necessity, sugar created them through industrial exploitation on a scale that would reshape the entire Atlantic world.

In medieval Europe, sugar was a medicine, a spice, a display of extreme wealth. Kings commissioned elaborate sculptures made entirely of sugar for royal feasts. It was as rare and precious as any Asian spice, accessible only to the wealthy elite. Fast forward to the nineteenth century, and sugar had become a staple of the working-class diet in Britain. How does a substance transition from being comparable to caviar to being comparable to bread?

The answer is the triangle trade, the economic engine that industrialized the Atlantic Ocean. European manufactured goods went to Africa. Enslaved people were taken to the Americas. Sugar and molasses returned to Europe. A closed loop of commerce that lasted for centuries.

The nature of this production must be understood clearly. Historian Sidney Mintz's analysis demonstrates that sugar plantations were industrial long before the Industrial Revolution. They were factories in the fields, with systematic labor organization, capital investment schedules, and production quotas. But these factories depended on what Mintz termed a 'false commodity': human beings treated as capital, as machinery.

Karl Marx observed this connection directly. 'Without slavery, there is no cotton. Without cotton, no modern industry.' The same logic applies to sugar with equal force. Sugar was literally the calories that powered the European labor force during industrialization.

Consider the factory worker in Manchester during the height of the Industrial Revolution. Working fourteen-hour shifts in brutal conditions, these laborers were calorie-deficient and exhausted. Sugary tea became their sustenance: a cheap, hot stimulant that provided quick energy bursts sufficient to keep the industrial machine running. That sugar was produced by enslaved people in Jamaica. The Manchester factory worker and the Caribbean slave were linked in a closed loop of exploitation, each sustaining the other's misery.

Sugar, tea, and tobacco became the solace of the working class. Not because these substances were nutritious or beneficial, but because they were cheap sources of energy and stimulation that allowed industrial capitalism to function. A packet of sugar is not merely a sweetener. It is an energy source that drove the Industrial Age, its whiteness concealing a history as dark as any in human memory.

## The Birth of the Individual

Iron built cities. Salt and sugar fueled the bodies that inhabited them. But one material did something even more remarkable: it rewired human psychology itself.

Before glass mirrors, what did people see when they looked at themselves? Pools of water gave distorted reflections. Polished bronze or copper might show a vague shape, perhaps enough to confirm that a helmet was positioned correctly, but reflecting only about twenty percent of available light. Nobody could see themselves clearly. Nobody could observe the texture of their own skin, the dilation of their own pupils, the specific features that made their face unique.

In a world without mirrors, identity was necessarily communal. People were defined by their village, their family, their trade. John the Blacksmith. Mary of the Valley. Individuals saw other people clearly every day of their lives but never truly saw themselves. The self was not a distinct visual entity but a node in a network of social relationships.

Then, in the fifteenth century, Venetian glassmakers perfected the technology of backing clear glass with metal amalgams. Suddenly, for the first time in human history, people could see crystal-clear reflections of themselves.

Historian Ian Mortimer argues that this technological development triggered what he calls the rise of the individual. The correlation between mirror availability and cultural shifts is remarkable. Self-portraiture in art emerged and flourished. Artists began painting themselves because for the first time they could actually see themselves with clarity. Literature transformed as well, with the rise of autobiography and the first-person novel. People began writing about 'I' and their internal emotional states because they had begun to view themselves as separate, observable entities.

Even architecture changed. Private bedrooms became valuable. Privacy itself became a cultural value. Before the mirror, there was far less separation between self and group. After the mirror, the individual became the fundamental unit of society.

The ancient Greeks knew about reflections. The myth of Narcissus warned about the dangers of becoming obsessed with one's own reflection in a pool. He fell in love with his image and died for it. It was a warning about self-obsession, and we have proceeded to ignore it thoroughly. Modern humans carry mirrors in their pockets, calling them selfie cameras, and are arguably more obsessed with self-image than any previous generation.

But the function of mirrors varied dramatically across cultures. In Mesoamerica, obsidian mirrors were not for grooming. They were tools for divination, for communicating with the divine, for looking into the other side. In China, bronze mirrors were often used to ward off evil spirits. The reflective surface was the same, but the cultural software running on it was completely different. In the West, the glass mirror gave birth to the ego.

## The Four Pillars of the Modern World

If asked what age we live in, most people would say the Information Age or the Silicon Age. Materials scientist Vaclav Smil argues they would be wrong.

Silicon is essential for control and communication. It processes information, enables the recording and broadcasting of data, and powers the digital infrastructure of modern life. But silicon has a fundamental limitation: you cannot live in a microchip. You cannot eat software.

Smil identifies what he calls the four pillars of modern civilization: ammonia, plastic, steel, and cement. These are the materials that actually keep humanity alive, and their importance dwarfs silicon by orders of magnitude.

Ammonia sounds like cleaning fluid to most people, but its primary use is nitrogen fertilizer. The Haber-Bosch process, developed in the early twentieth century, creates synthetic ammonia by fixing nitrogen from the atmosphere. The statistics are staggering: without this process, global agriculture could support perhaps three or four billion people. The current global population exceeds eight billion. Roughly half of the nitrogen atoms in any human body today, the actual atoms comprising DNA and proteins, originated in a factory. Half of humanity's physical substance is, in a very real sense, synthetic.

Steel and cement form the skeletons and skins of modern cities. Humanity produces more of these materials now than at any point in history. Production is not declining; it is accelerating.

The concept of dematerialization creates an illusion. A smartphone consolidates what once required a camera, flashlight, map, stereo, and dozens of other devices into a single small object. It appears that humanity is using less material. But the device in your hand is only the visible interface of a vast material infrastructure. Server farms running cloud services are massive concrete and steel structures. Delivery networks bringing packages to your door require steel trucks, plastic packaging, and asphalt roads made with cement. While individual consumer devices shrink, absolute material consumption is skyrocketing.

The inequality dimension is equally significant. Affluent nations consume staggering quantities of these pillar materials. Forty to sixty kilograms of sugar and sweeteners per person per year. Vast amounts of plastic and steel embedded in every aspect of daily life. Meanwhile, developing nations are still building their basic infrastructure, still trying to construct the material foundations that wealthy countries take for granted.

Silicon is the dashboard of modern civilization. The engine is still built of heavy materials: ammonia, steel, cement, and plastic.

## The Original Material

One material underlies everything discussed so far, so fundamental that it often goes unmentioned: wood.

You cannot smelt copper or iron without fire. For thousands of years, fire meant wood, or charcoal made from wood. The link between civilization and deforestation is a recurring theme throughout history. The more societies advanced materially, the more forests they consumed.

The Minoans were theorized to have collapsed because they cut down all their trees. The idea was that they used so much wood to smelt copper for bronze that they ruined their island's ecology. More recent evidence points to the Thera volcanic eruption as the primary cause of Minoan decline, but the deforestation itself was documented and real.

The Romans understood timber as a strategic military asset. Rome prohibited Macedonians from cutting timber, not to protect the environment, but to prevent them from building a navy. No trees meant no ships. No ships meant no rival fleet to challenge Roman supremacy. It was an ancient form of oil embargo.

The shift to iron, praised earlier for its democratizing effects, actually accelerated environmental destruction. Iron requires higher temperatures, which demands more charcoal, which means more wood. The Iron Age led to massive deforestation across Cyprus, the Mediterranean, and eventually the entire known world. The humblest plowman getting his iron tool meant millions of trees cut to make those tools, and millions more cut by those tools to create farmland.

Every material solves a problem and creates a new one. History has always been a double-edged iron pike.

## What Age Are We?

Thomsen sat in Copenhagen sorting stone from bronze from iron, establishing a framework for understanding the human past through materials. That framework revealed how bronze created elites while iron empowered farmers, how salt created empires and sugar fueled industrial workforces, how mirrors created the psychological individual.

The trajectory is clear. Humanity began with what could be found on the ground: stone, wood. Then came materials that could be extracted and modified: bronze, iron. Then materials that could be chemically synthesized: ammonia, plastics. Future materials may include multi-ferroics or room-temperature superconductors, substances that could revolutionize energy transmission as thoroughly as the steam engine revolutionized manufacturing.

But there is a final, sobering question. Archaeologists look back at the Stone Age, the Bronze Age, the Iron Age. If archaeologists dig through our remains in a thousand years, what age will they say we lived in?

Will they call it the Silicon Age? Unlikely. Silicon chips are fragile and will likely have degraded entirely. Will they call it the Plastic Age? That is a strong possibility. Humanity is leaving a layer of plastic in the geological record that will persist for millennia, a synthetic stratum that future scientists will unmistakably identify.

Or perhaps they will call it the Carbon Age. Not because we used carbon tools, but because of the carbon we released into the atmosphere. An invisible layer with the biggest impact of all.

We are defined by what we leave behind.

## The Material World

Look around whatever room you occupy right now. Do not see a phone. See the sand that was melted into glass, the rare earth elements mined from specific geological deposits, the plastic housing derived from petroleum. Do not see a desk. See the tree that was felled, the iron nails that required ore and charcoal and centuries of metallurgical knowledge. Do not see a window. See the silica transformed by heat, the mirror that might show your reflection and thereby reinforce your sense of individual identity.

You are not surrounded by objects. You are surrounded by history.

Every substance in your environment carries the weight of millennia: the trade routes that moved tin from Cornwall to Mesopotamia, the forests cleared to smelt the metal, the enslaved populations who harvested the sugar that sweetened your ancestors' tea, the Venetian artisans who first created mirrors clear enough to show a human face in sharp detail.

The great men of history, the kings and generals and conquerors, worked within constraints they never chose and often did not understand. They built their empires with bronze and iron, sustained them with salt and sugar, and saw themselves in mirrors that transformed their very concept of selfhood. They were not the authors of history. They were characters in a story written by materials.

The next time you hold a piece of metal, taste something sweet, or catch your reflection in a window, remember that you are touching the forces that truly shaped civilization. The substances are still shaping us, still determining our possibilities, still writing the history that future generations will study. And they will study it, inevitably, through the materials we leave behind.
key_takeaways: Christian Jorgensen Thomsen created the Three Age System (Stone, Bronze, Iron) not through field archaeology but by analyzing patterns in museum collections, establishing material-based historical analysis
Bronze was an aristocratic material requiring international tin trade routes spanning from Afghanistan to Cornwall, reinforcing elite hierarchies rather than transforming common life
Iron democratized metal through carburization technology, not tin shortages, enabling cheap tools and weapons that reshaped social structures from the bottom up
Salt was the first international commodity and state monopoly, with its taxation fueling revolutions from France to India's independence movement
Sugar transformed from aristocratic spice to working-class staple through the triangle trade, creating an industrial system of exploitation that fueled the Industrial Revolution
Glass mirrors in 15th-century Venice triggered the rise of individual identity, influencing the emergence of self-portraiture, autobiography, and the concept of privacy

Vaclav Smil's four pillars of modern civilization, ammonia, steel, cement, and plastic, are far more fundamental than silicon, with half of human body nitrogen now originating from industrial processes
Wood underlies all metallurgical progress, with iron's higher temperatures accelerating deforestation and every material advancement creating new environmental problems

entities.name: Christian Jorgensen Thomsen
entities.description: Danish antiquarian who developed the Three Age System (Stone, Bronze, Iron) while organizing the National Museum of Denmark's collections. His insight that artifacts of different materials were never found together in the same archaeological layers revolutionized the study of prehistory.

entities.name: Sidney Mintz
entities.description: American anthropologist whose book 'Sweetness and Power' (1985) analyzed how sugar transformed from aristocratic luxury to working-class staple, revealing the connections between Caribbean slavery, industrial capitalism, and European diet.

entities.name: Vaclav Smil
entities.description: Czech-Canadian scientist and policy analyst who studies energy, environmental change, and material requirements of civilization. His concept of the 'four pillars' (ammonia, steel, cement, plastic) challenges the notion that we live in a dematerialized Silicon Age.

entities.name: Ian Mortimer
entities.description: British historian known for immersive historical writing. His work on the cultural impact of mirrors argues that clear glass reflections triggered 'the rise of the individual' by allowing people to see themselves as distinct visual entities for the first time.

entities.name: Three Age System
entities.description: Archaeological periodization dividing human prehistory into Stone Age, Bronze Age, and Iron Age based on the primary materials used for tools and weapons. Developed by Thomsen and still used as the standard framework for prehistoric archaeology.

entities.name: Carburization
entities.description: Metallurgical process where iron is heated in contact with carbon (charcoal) to create steel or case-hardened iron. This technology, not tin shortages, enabled the transition from Bronze Age to Iron Age by making iron superior to bronze for tools and weapons.

entities.name: Triangular Trade
entities.description: Atlantic trade network connecting Europe, Africa, and the Americas. European goods went to Africa, enslaved people were transported to American plantations, and sugar, molasses, and other commodities returned to Europe. This system industrialized sugar production and fueled European economic development.

entities.name: Haber-Bosch Process
entities.description: Industrial process for synthesizing ammonia from atmospheric nitrogen and hydrogen. Developed by Fritz Haber and Carl Bosch, it enabled mass production of nitrogen fertilizers. Without it, global agriculture could support only 3-4 billion people instead of the current 8+ billion.

entities.name: Salt March
entities.description: Act of nonviolent civil disobedience led by Mahatma Gandhi to protest the British salt monopoly in India. Gandhi walked 240 miles to the sea to make salt from seawater, highlighting imperial control over a basic necessity of life.

entities.name: Gabelle
entities.description: French tax on salt that was universally despised and contributed to revolutionary sentiment. The gabelle exemplified how taxation of biological necessities could become a flashpoint for political revolt.

entities.name: Venetian Mirrors
entities.description: Glass mirrors backed with metal amalgams, perfected by Venetian glassmakers on Murano. These were the first mirrors to provide truly clear reflections, allegedly contributing to the rise of individual identity and self-consciousness in Western culture.

entities.name: Bronze Age Tin Trade
entities.description: Long-distance trade networks supplying tin for bronze production. Routes stretched from mines in Afghanistan and Cornwall to Mediterranean civilizations, creating the first international supply chains and requiring merchant classes and elite patronage.

entities.name: Iron Age Cyprus
entities.description: Cyprus appears to have been a major hub for iron technology innovation, including carburization. Archaeological evidence such as the iron pike from Tomb 417 at Lapithos shows early military applications of advanced ironworking.

entities.name: Material Determinism
entities.description: Historical and philosophical perspective arguing that material conditions, including available resources and technologies, fundamentally shape social structures, economies, and even human psychology, rather than individuals or ideas driving historical change.

quiz_questions.question: Why did the transition from Bronze Age to Iron Age occur, according to recent archaeological evidence?

options.A: Bronze trade routes collapsed due to tin shortages
options.B: Iron was always superior but people preferred bronze aesthetically
options.C: Carburization technology made processed iron superior to bronze
options.D: Climate change eliminated copper deposits across the Mediterranean

quiz_questions.explanation: Chemical analyses of bronze objects from the transition period show tin was still available. The real innovation was carburization, heating iron with carbon to create harder steel, which made iron superior to bronze for tools and weapons.

quiz_questions.question: What made bronze an 'aristocratic material' that reinforced elite hierarchies?

options.A: Bronze was considered more beautiful than other metals
options.B: Laws prohibited commoners from owning bronze
options.C: Tin required for bronze was geologically rare and demanded international trade networks
options.D: Bronze smelting required secret knowledge only priests possessed

quiz_questions.explanation: While copper was relatively common, tin was geologically rare, requiring trade routes stretching from Afghanistan to Cornwall. This created the need for merchant classes, ships, and wealthy elites to fund and protect trade, making bronze fundamentally a material of the wealthy.

quiz_questions.question: According to Ian Mortimer's thesis, how did glass mirrors affect Western civilization?

options.A: They enabled more accurate scientific observation
options.B: They triggered the rise of individual identity and self-consciousness
options.C: They allowed for better architectural design

quiz_questions.explanation: Mortimer argues that before clear mirrors, identity was communal rather than individual. When people could finally see themselves clearly, cultural shifts followed: self-portraiture in art, autobiography in literature, and privacy as a value. The mirror created the modern ego.

quiz_questions.question: What are Vaclav Smil's 'four pillars of modern civilization'?

options.B: Oil, natural gas, coal, and nuclear

quiz_questions.explanation: Smil argues that despite talk of a 'Silicon Age,' modern civilization actually depends on ammonia (fertilizer), plastic, steel, and cement. Without Haber-Bosch ammonia synthesis alone, global agriculture could only support 3-4 billion people instead of 8+ billion.
